Title: The Great VC Reshuffle: OpenAI‚Äôs $500B Restructuring, A16z‚Äôs $10B Mega-Fund, and Why Two-Thirds of Series B Investments Fail
URL: https://www.saastr.com/the-great-vc-reshuffle-openais-500b-restructuring-a16zs-10b-mega-fund-and-why-two-thirds-of-series-b-investments-fail/
Time Published: 2025-10-30T17:40:36Z
Full Content:
by Jason Lemkin | Blog Posts We‚Äôre back!! 20VC x SaaStr with Harry, Rory and Jason! Bottom Line Up Front: Three seismic shifts hit venture this week. OpenAI completed the most significant corporate restructuring in tech history, clearing the path for a potential $2 trillion IPO while Sam Altman keeps zero equity. Andreessen Horowitz raised $10 billion‚Äîbut when you break down the individual funds, they‚Äôre more beatable than the headlines suggest. And new data proves what great investors always knew: two-thirds of Series B investments return less than 2x, making picking more critical than ever. Meanwhile, companies like Mercor hit $500M in revenue in record time, and the debate over when founders should sell intensifies as regulatory risk reshapes M&A. The big news this week: OpenAI successfully cut deals with Microsoft, Delaware, and California attorneys general to implement their long-awaited restructuring. They‚Äôre now a proper public benefit corporation (PBC)‚Äîsimilar to Patagonia‚Äîwith a $135 billion charitable foundation owning roughly 20%, Microsoft owning 27%, and employees owning another 20%+. What This Actually Means: The most shocking detail? Sam Altman will have zero equity in the restructured entity. Think about that for a moment‚Äîwe‚Äôre simultaneously watching Elon Musk argue for a trillion-dollar pay package while the CEO of OpenAI owns nothing in a $500 billion company. Jason Lemkin noted the absurdity: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got Elon Musk arguing he deserves a trillion dollar pay package‚Ä¶ and everyone was saying show Sam the money when he was fired as CEO over a very long weekend, right, the night of knives or whatever‚Ä¶ Fast forward to today, that same nonprofit is still in charge and he has no shares. We‚Äôve never seen someone own nothing, have we? Like this. Have we ever seen anybody own nothing? It‚Äôs crazy.‚Äù Rory O‚ÄôDriscoll explained the power dynamics: ‚ÄúIt gives him in some ways more power as well as less power. You can‚Äôt assail the man for capitalism when his other billion-dollar entities are the ones that let him finish off the McLaren collection.‚Äù Microsoft emerges as a clear winner, turning their $13 billion investment into a 10x return with ongoing revenue share and Azure contracts. O‚ÄôDriscoll was emphatic: ‚ÄúMicrosoft corporate development and lawyers deserve a gold star from their shareholders in a way that frankly Microsoft R&D does not. And the proof of this is this morning Microsoft stock is up nicely. They‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòThank you for the hundred billion. We‚Äôre up.'‚Äù The charitable foundation also wins big‚Äî$135 billion is, as O‚ÄôDriscoll put it, ‚Äúa significant contribution to whatever good they hopefully will do with that money. There‚Äôs $135 billion out there that‚Äôs not going into someone‚Äôs pockets to buy yachts, boats and football teams. It‚Äôs actually going to try and solve world‚Äôs problems.‚Äù He added the historical perspective: ‚ÄúI would have laughed in 2016 at the people who started OpenAI saying we want to do good for the world. But at a big picture level they succeeded‚Äîthey built something worth $130 billion which is a foundation that they can be proud of.‚Äù Here‚Äôs where it gets interesting for founders and investors: OpenAI now has a clear path to what could be the most popular retail IPO in history. Lemkin was direct: ‚ÄúI just can‚Äôt think of a retail IPO that would be more popular than OpenAI. Just bringing everyone out of the woodwork to put a little bit of their life savings into it‚Äîto ignore even if the valuation makes no sense. This would have to be the most popular retail IPO of all time, right?‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll agreed: ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre exactly right. People aren‚Äôt going to be reading the prospectus and saying maybe we won‚Äôt make profits. They‚Äôre not going to be reading the thing about $250 billion of cloud commits to third parties. They‚Äôre just going to be like, let me get some of that OpenAI.‚Äù Current math: At $500 billion with roughly $12 billion in revenue, they‚Äôre trading at ~40x revenue. O‚ÄôDriscoll broke down the trajectory: ‚ÄúAt even at 5x revenues, my god, that‚Äôs six billion‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs kind of, you know, 40 times gap and if it‚Äôs 20 billion it‚Äôs 25 times AR run rate. My guess is it would take two years in the normal course but you might see that euphoria moment. It‚Äôs within the trajectory, it‚Äôs within the strike zone if anything like the current growth rate continues.‚Äù But he added the critical caveat: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre trading at 40 times revenues and your growth rate slows, it‚Äôs nasty and you fall sheer.‚Äù Lemkin pointed out another crucial advantage: ‚ÄúThis unlocks maybe four times more equity for them potentially if the public markets are different than the private because of the potential valuation they could IPO. They may need that‚Äîthey may need an extra 200 billion to go the distance.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll noted the banker feeding frenzy to come: ‚ÄúEvery banker on the planet will be making decks as we speak and calling on Mr. Altman and Mr. Taylor. They might pretty much do it for half nothing just to be on the biggest IPO of all times.‚Äù Everyone‚Äôs talking about a16z‚Äôs massive $10 billion fundraise, but when you break down the funds, it‚Äôs actually more reasonable than the headline suggests: Lemkin had the contrarian take: ‚ÄúI thought they were small. And what I mean is I didn‚Äôt think it was small until I saw the breakdown of the funds. At first when we talked about this before, I‚Äôm like 10 billion‚Äîthat‚Äôs unprecedented. But when I look at that and the new Sequoia fund, $200 million Sequoia seed fund‚Äîthat‚Äôs not that big compared to 20 VC‚Ä¶ 1.5 billion for AI apps when you‚Äôre investing in 11 labs and friends and Replit doesn‚Äôt seem to get you very far.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúWhen you break apart the funds, I really don‚Äôt think Sequoia having $200 million is that different than what Harry has. And I don‚Äôt think one and a half billion for their AI app funds‚ÄîI think it‚Äôs only twice the scale. So I just don‚Äôt think air cover is an excuse. You have to work twice as hard as they do.‚Äù The Red Army Strategy O‚ÄôDriscoll provided the big picture: ‚ÄúAndre Andreessen Horowitz is the red army of the venture industry now. They got the 10 billion and they‚Äôre going to march it forward. The amount of self-knowledge embodied in that is stunning. There‚Äôs one of my favorite expressions from the Russian Red Army which is quantity has a quality all its own. In other words, when you want to take Berlin, at some point what you do is you just get two million people willing to die and you march them forward.‚Äù But he also acknowledged the scale advantages: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not of course it‚Äôs 10 billion. It‚Äôs 10 billion of 30% carry and 10 billion of 2% fees and 10 billion of all this. The definition of a good strategy is if you have a strategy that doesn‚Äôt allow you to have to work that hard. And therefore by definition having 10 billion is a good strategy.‚Äù Harry Stebbings added the structural insight: ‚ÄúThat is a lot more money for management fees to pay great people. That is a lot more carry. That is a lot nicer offices which founders do get wowed by‚Äîlike it or not they get wowed by it. That is a lot more events to host where you can have serendipity.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll explained the optionality advantage: ‚ÄúYou can spray if you have option value if you‚Äôre just doing options. If you spray and that‚Äôs the only way you make your money, the probability of being wrong is just too high. The more bankroll you have to build up option value‚Ä¶ the more option value you have at the back end because you have a $10 trillion fund, the easier it is to spray because you can amortize the cost of the losses over the one winner.‚Äù Stebbings noted the LP dynamic most don‚Äôt understand: ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt often understand the stapling that is required to be in these funds, which is if you‚Äôre an LP and you want to be in the early stage fund, you will often very often with top tier brands have to put in two times that into another fund to get that $1 in the other. And you don‚Äôt get your pick of which fund. Very often you have to be across all of them.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll summed it up: ‚ÄúBundling and rent extraction is fully understood.‚Äù While everyone obsesses over foundation models, Mercor quietly hit $500 million in revenue faster than any company in history‚Äîjust 17 months to reach that milestone. They‚Äôre now valued at $10 billion, up from $2 billion just eight months ago. What They Actually Do: O‚ÄôDriscoll explained the business: ‚ÄúThey provide humans with specialist knowledge to‚Äîand their customers are the large foundation model companies‚Äîand what they do is they bring this human talent to bear to help the foundation model companies train the models by providing human feedback. You people would have heard RLHF‚Äîreinforcement learning through human feedback‚Äîthese are the humans that do that.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm OpenAI and I want to teach my latest model how to do advanced math, what I need is a whole bunch of doctorates and PhDs who understand math that are available to pose questions to the model, judge model questions, give feedback on which answer is correct. By doing that, you effectively‚Äîby giving this human feedback‚ÄîI think of it as you pound the model into submission where it eventually says, ‚ÄòOkay, I‚Äôve learned this shit by adjusting the weights.'‚Äù The evolution is stunning: ‚ÄúFive years ago, we were labeling cats. And you had people often overseas charged with labeling cats and not getting a lot of money. I think Mercor realized that the market today is not labeling cats. It‚Äôs in fact answering complex physics questions, math questions, bio questions because the models know how to label cats now and what they need to do is the outer edges of human knowledge.‚Äù The Bull Case: Stebbings broke down the expanding value proposition: ‚ÄúIt all started with talent acquisition‚Äîif you got the talent and could provide it, fantastic. We‚Äôll pay you. Pillar two is get the talent, now we want data acquisition‚Äîyou provide it to us, not we extract it. And you measure the quality of it too. And now we‚Äôre adding the third pillar, which is the implementation layer‚Äîwe expect you to implement it efficiently and make sure our models get off the ground more effectively. And with that, you also see increased pricing and the willingness to spend much, much more from the model providers.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll on the growth opportunity: ‚ÄúThe growth isn‚Äôt surprising because if you think about it, these model companies have grown faster than any company in human history. They‚Äôre spending $400 billion on compute. They‚Äôre probably spending $4 billion dollars on RLHF and they were spending zero five years ago. It‚Äôs an explosive growth market.‚Äù The Bear Case: But Stebbings identified the concentration risk: ‚ÄúYou have concentration of buyer unlike any other industry. Two buyers are 50% plus of every one of these labeling providers‚Äô revenue. So there is real revenue concentration there. It‚Äôs high quality customers but you do have that dynamic as well.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll was even more direct on the structural challenges: ‚ÄúYour margin profile is not amazing because the gross revenue is 500 million but you give 70% of it to the doctors and the mathematicians who are doing all whatever it is‚Äîsome percentage I‚Äôm not going to speculate‚Äîand then the second fact you have against you is massive customer concentration. And at some point they‚Äôre going to say, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm giving you $200 million which means you‚Äôre making 30% on that‚Äî$60 million‚Äîhell maybe you do it for $40 million,‚Äô right?‚Äù He concluded with the ultimate framing: ‚ÄúFrom a long-term value extraction perspective, you prefer to be OpenAI and have 800 million customers than to be Mercor and have two. When you look at those positives and negatives, this is fundamentally a bet that the AI capex train will keep running for two or three or four more years.‚Äù Lemkin added the timeline caveat: ‚ÄúOpenAI is not going to focus on getting efficient until it‚Äôs dealt with hyperrowth. So as long as it‚Äôs not getting efficient, you probably can lean in. If it slows down, then the positives‚Äîwhich is the growth rate‚Äîgoes away and then all the negatives come back to bite you.‚Äù On the valuation at $10 billion with $500M revenue, Stebbings noted: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only 20 times revenue. So like it doesn‚Äôt seem‚Äîthis is where actually we‚Äôre seeing revenue compression.‚Äù But O‚ÄôDriscoll provided the sobering underwriting math: ‚ÄúYou should be underwriting anything to a 3x. So you got to be 30 billion to make it worth your while and 30 billion‚Ä¶ at even at 5x revenues, my god, that‚Äôs six billion. You‚Äôre underwriting a lot of training data.‚Äù Ramp raising again at $30 billion (up from $23 billion) prompted questions about whether constant fundraising is now just part of the playbook. Why The Skepticism: Lemkin was blunt: ‚ÄúTo me, going from $23 billion to $30 billion, I don‚Äôt even consider it an up round. It‚Äôs not enough. Let‚Äôs say I was a seed investor, I‚Äôve probably had a token of dilution. So let‚Äôs imagine I‚Äôm down to 2%, which would be great. I have a $400 million position at the last round. Right now, it‚Äôs worth $480 million with dilution after this next round. I mean, it‚Äôs a lot, but it‚Äôs not doubling my position like a classic round is.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúThese little rounds‚Äî22, 25, 30‚Äîand with a lot of AI companies, a lot of dilution or a lot of others, you could see 10% annual dilution in these companies or more. You might go from 22 to 30 and have the same price per share. It‚Äôs possible. I just don‚Äôt really care about these micro step-ups that look great‚Äîyou‚Äôre like 30 billion‚Äîwell if the last round was at 10, impressive. If the last round‚Äôs at three like Mercor, impressive. Here I‚Äôm like, meh, that‚Äôs cute.‚Äù Why It Makes Sense: O‚ÄôDriscoll explained the capital needs: ‚ÄúThere does appear to be a combination of insane demand for the stock, an ability to use that to create this aura of inevitability. And this is more than most companies‚Äîthis is one where constant growth requires lots of capital because you‚Äôre in a capital advancing business. So you probably have every dollar you add of revenue takes $5 of capital because you got to finance purchases‚Äîyou‚Äôre effectively recreating Amex. So it may well be that there‚Äôs a larger demand for capital here than the average deal.‚Äù On the valuation progression, he noted: ‚ÄúSomeone‚Äôs lending you $4 billion of that, they‚Äôre probably going to want a $1 billion equity cushion. Going from 23 billion to 30 billion‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs say I was a seed investor with 2%‚ÄîI have a $400 million position at the last round, right now it‚Äôs worth $480 million with dilution.‚Äù The Public vs Private Debate: O‚ÄôDriscoll made a critical distinction: ‚ÄúAnother spin on what you‚Äôre saying is with the exception of the new AI companies, that probably is the kind of IRR you should expect to get in a mature growth private company. There‚Äôs really early and late stage venture and then there‚Äôs venture for companies that already could comfortably be public and I think we need a different word for that‚Äîit‚Äôs not even late stage‚Äîit‚Äôs private as public, could just as easily be a small midcap stock at this point in time public.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt expect midcap stocks to gap up 3x in a year‚Äîyou expect the overall market will go by 11%, the best companies grow 30-40% year-on-year. There‚Äôs no reason to assume that the return to the stock should be different just because it‚Äôs held in a different corporate structure. The company is the company independent if it‚Äôs public or private.‚Äù Lemkin countered: ‚ÄúYou just said we‚Äôre still underwriting Harry asked you what we‚Äôre underwriting to. You said at least 3x. So if I‚Äôm going to underwrite to 3x and I did the last Ramp round at 23, it‚Äôs not really getting me to my 3x.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll clarified: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre confusing your pronouns. You‚Äôre trying to underwrite to a 3x. If you‚Äôre running money doing companies at 30 billion pre, you‚Äôre probably not underwriting to an overall 3x on your fund. I don‚Äôt think you are underwriting to a 3x when you‚Äôre doing ultra late stage billion-dollar revenue run rate $30 billion valuations and you‚Äôre definitely not underwriting to a 30% IRR.‚Äù New data from Carter looked at all 547 Series B investments from 2018. The results are sobering for anyone who thinks picking doesn‚Äôt matter. The Distribution: The Math: O‚ÄôDriscoll analyzed the data: ‚ÄúIf you hit those three buckets correctly, the blended return‚ÄîI know it from our fund model‚Äîis 3.7x gross, 3x net to the LP. So if you look at that business, if you get enough slots in the buckets, right, in each of the buckets‚Äîthe good buckets, the 5x bucket and the 10x bucket‚Äîyou end up with a 3x net to the LP. So the first piece of good news is if you do it right, the return was available to you.‚Äù But he emphasized the picking challenge: ‚ÄúJason picked on the negative which is two-thirds of all deals are less than a 2x which means they just don‚Äôt help. And what it says is picking is so important because if you skew instead of 66%, if you skew 75-80% in that less than 2x bucket, your math doesn‚Äôt work. And it‚Äôs not that hard to be that bad because on average it‚Äôs 66%.‚Äù The Brutal Truth About Series B: Only 1 in 3 Deals Even Double Investors‚Äô Money, Per Latest Carta Data Does Spray and Pray Work? Lemkin disagreed with the spray characterization: ‚ÄúAt series B, everyone thinks they‚Äôre a great picker, don‚Äôt they? This isn‚Äôt pre-seed. Everyone‚Äôs a great picker at series B, right?‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll responded: ‚ÄúEveryone thinks they‚Äôre a great picker. Not everyone is a great picker. But the third sentence is you have to be a great picker to win. I think if you don‚Äôt pick, if you‚Äôre not a good picker, you will end up with more‚Ä¶ If you skew 75-80% in that less than 2x bucket, your math doesn‚Äôt work. It requires a fair amount of discipline and picking to pull this off. I don‚Äôt think the spray and pray strategy would work here.‚Äù He identified three distinct strategies: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs actually three approaches. There‚Äôs picking, there‚Äôs spraying, and then the third one which someone big like Andre can do which is optioning. You can spray if you have option value if you‚Äôre just doing options. But if you spray and that‚Äôs the only way you make your money, the probability of being wrong is just too high.‚Äù On the a16z seed strategy with 72 seed bets (compared to number two at 27), Stebbings noted: ‚ÄúExactly to your point there, Rory, you said you can‚Äôt win without being a great picker. I‚Äôm not saying Andre are not great pickers, but you can if you have 72 option bets.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll agreed: ‚ÄúThere are three strategies. There‚Äôs spraying, picking, and optioning. Optioning allows you to spray more. Once upon a time, you thought seed was all about option value and anything beyond that wasn‚Äôt. Because we‚Äôre dealing with gargantuan sums of money, it is now plausible that for some people A‚Äôs and B‚Äôs are partially options. If you‚Äôre going to deploy $200 million in the growth round, you don‚Äôt want to be totally slipshod at the A and the B, but you can think of it as more option value. That‚Äôs absolutely a superpower that a wall of money gives you.‚Äù Even at Seed: On whether spray works at seed, O‚ÄôDriscoll did the math: ‚ÄúGoing back to the Carter data, there were 547 series B‚Äôs in 2018. I‚Äôm going to guess graduation rate probably implies 800 A‚Äôs. That probably implies 1,600 seeds. So even what you are pejoratively calling spray and pray is doing 50 deals out of 1,600. There‚Äôs still a huge element of picking involved in that.‚Äù He identified the only exception: ‚ÄúThe only people on the planet who have a structural business where they can de-emphasize picking because they can write checks‚Äîoption checks at scale‚Äîis Y Combinator because they have a structured advantage in terms of their economics. They are the only people who‚Äôve built a mass production seed business.‚Äù On why even the single best outcome doesn‚Äôt justify true spray: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll always be true that if you pick the single largest outlier in any vintage‚Äîlike if one of those deals was Figma where the B made 100x‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs 300x, if you did an index and did every deal equally, it‚Äôs only a 0.2x. If you put a dollar into everything, your Figma check doesn‚Äôt return the fund. Maybe an OpenAI would‚Äîmaybe there is one deal so big that it would literally return the vintage such that if you just bought the entire vintage you‚Äôre good‚Äîthat probably happens maybe once every decade or two.‚Äù Synthesia, the AI video generation company at $150M ARR, reportedly turned down a $3 billion acquisition offer from Adobe. They‚Äôre now raising north of $3 billion instead. The Case for Selling: Lemkin was direct: ‚ÄúI would tell him to take it unless you‚Äôre 100% sure you‚Äôre going to build a $20 billion public company, $10 billion public company. And if you are, do it. I like to stress the test. So I‚Äôm not saying that‚Äôs the right thing to do, but I want to be the guy that gives that advice.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúEven 10 is not really worth it for a founder. It is worth it for the VCs. Excel gets another play. 3 to 10 for Excel‚Äîhuge difference. So let‚Äôs say they own 15% out of a‚Äîwhat‚Äî$450 million fund. Instead of a 1x fund returner, it could be a two or 3x. You make that bet as a VC all day long. For the founder, let‚Äôs say owns 10%‚Äîwhat the hell‚Äôs the difference? There‚Äôs no difference.‚Äù On the reality of wealth: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had billionaires on our show. You‚Äôve had billionaires, Harry. I don‚Äôt think Jeff Lawson would be living a better life with half the money or twice the money. It‚Äôs the same dude.‚Äù The Underrated Question: Lemkin raised the question no one asks: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs another thing that‚Äôs under-discussed and I‚Äôve had this conversation twice with founders in the last 12 to 18 months in similar situations: Are you really an IPO guy? I love everything about this company, I love the founders, I love everything. There‚Äôs nothing negative. And I told them to take the offer even though I didn‚Äôt want them to as an investor. I told them to take the offer because I said, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre such a great set of founders, but I don‚Äôt know if today I see you living the public company CEO life. I just don‚Äôt see it‚Äîthe way you have to do it, the constraints, the stress.'‚Äù He explained the stakes: ‚ÄúYou have to assume it‚Äôs IPO or bust. And if you‚Äôre not that guy, then you‚Äôre going to bring in an outside CEO or it‚Äôs just a mess. So that‚Äôs the question I have: Do you really want to run a public company for real?‚Äù On the weight of being public: ‚ÄúI was at this Dreamforce Benioff dinner. I saw maybe 10 public company B2B CEOs that we know that have all been on Harry‚Äôs show and Rory‚Äôs invested in some of them. And it was great and it was fun. I got some hugs. But man, the stress on those guys‚Äîyou could just smell it out of the pores. The weight‚Äîthey weren‚Äôt stressed, no one was stressed‚Äîthe weight of being a public company CEO‚Äîit‚Äôs so heavy today. We could see it when we‚Äôd had Jeff Lawson on and Cliff didn‚Äôt have any of it at Canva‚Äîhe didn‚Äôt have any of the weight crushing.‚Äù The Case for Taking the Risk: O‚ÄôDriscoll provided the growth analysis: ‚ÄúVictor, I admire Synthesia enormously as a company. We tried to contact them‚Äîthey didn‚Äôt get back to me. They got the deal done. I‚Äôm so disappointed. We have another investment in the space. I love the space. I admire Synthesia a ton and many of the investors there. I think the first question is how do you feel about the business? And you threw out a statistic there‚Äîthey said they‚Äôre at 100 million in ARR when they took the Adobe money in April. I checked. And if they really have gone from 100 to 150 in less than 6 months, then I can make this conversation really quick. There‚Äôs no way they should sell because that thing‚Äôs exploding.‚Äù He added the category perspective: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great category. There‚Äôs a reason we made another investment in the space. We like the category. I think there‚Äôs runway there for that kind of human interface to compute.‚Äù On the LP pressure question, Lemkin pushed back: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe that. I don‚Äôt see it. I‚Äôve asked my LPs, I‚Äôve asked a few others. If you‚Äôre a strong manager‚Äîokay, if you have a track record and their goal is not a 3x seed fund, but if they really want 5x or north out of you‚Äîthey get the game is you got to keep playing another card. No matter what they say, I‚Äôve asked my LP and I guess it‚Äôs a small set‚Äîdo you want more money back? Even ask my most conservative LP like a university endowment that is small, that has stress‚ÄîI ask you want your money back, I mean with a gain‚Äîthey‚Äôre like no, we‚Äôre just telling you we‚Äôre really worried about it, like we really want DPI but we don‚Äôt want it. We want you to play another card.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll summarized the board conversation: ‚ÄúI always tell the CEO, ‚ÄòNow would be a really good time for you to look into your own heart and see how you feel. And if there‚Äôs something about the business that‚Äôs really worrying you and you haven‚Äôt told us, now would be a good time to share.‚Äô And sometimes stuff comes out.‚Äù Stebbings added the regulatory timeline dimension: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a Synthesia, you‚Äôre looking at Dylan and Figma going, ‚ÄòGod, do I want to put myself in that potential 18-month waiting period?‚Äô By which time I‚Äôll be $400 million in revenue being acquired for $3 billion. You think you‚Äôre getting this great multiple of‚Äîoh, they‚Äôre paying me 30 times revenue‚Äîbut the damn thing‚Äôs going to close in 18 months, by which time you might be down to 10 times.‚Äù Amazon announced their largest white-collar layoffs ever (10% of corporate staff), is losing cloud market share (from 50% in 2018 to 38% today), and had a major AWS outage causing billions in damage. The Timing Question: O‚ÄôDriscoll noted: ‚ÄúContrast this with Sergey Brin coming back to Google, everything else happening. Maybe this was a tough time for your founder to leave and go to Miami. Maybe this was not‚Äîmaybe it seemed like a very stable time to do a transition. Long time as CEO, but maybe this wasn‚Äôt the perfect age of maybe stepping down just before AI hit was suboptimal for Amazon.‚Äù Lemkin provided historical context: ‚ÄúJeff Bezos checked out right at the peak of the last era when products were frozen in time for a decade, when AWS was the same product for a year. So are most of the companies we invested in all three of us in 2021‚Äîthey were the same products as 2015. It was the great time to go to Miami because nothing was changing in the product. It was just going‚Äîjust stock prices were going up in revenue, but the products were the same. So why wouldn‚Äôt you retire? There‚Äôs not going to be any change.‚Äù The Counterargument: O‚ÄôDriscoll offered the alternative view: ‚ÄúOr maybe it was brilliant for Jeff because maybe the hook‚Äîbecause you‚Äôre implying in that that had he stayed all these bad things wouldn‚Äôt have happened. And it‚Äôs plausible just given his world top two or three entrepreneurial achievement of the last three decades.‚Äù But then he turned cynical: ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôve got a couple hundred billion dollars, my guess is you‚Äôre not maximizing money. You‚Äôre maximizing psychic pain and joy. My guess is his psychic joy in the last three or four years doing what he‚Äôs been doing has been significantly higher than the psychic pain that would have been involved in realizing you‚Äôve never done a big acquisition in your life, you got to do a huge corporate deal in AI to matter, and all those people you hired in ‚Äô21 trying to do the right thing for COVID and expand‚Äîyou all got to lay them off.‚Äù Lemkin was even blunter: ‚ÄúI think Bezos would lay off half his company in a fortnight if it was the right thing. I don‚Äôt think you even care.‚Äù The Problem Analysis: O‚ÄôDriscoll broke down Amazon‚Äôs challenges: ‚ÄúThe first problem is in their retail business they overinvested for COVID and now they‚Äôre trying to replace people with robotics because the technology is there and that‚Äôs just something that had to be done. And in cloud it‚Äôs less that their core AWS business has folded up. It‚Äôs like all the new compute which is 10x and 20x larger in terms of demand for these customers is AI-related compute and you‚Äôve neither built something compelling standalone nor have you partnered‚Äîexcept to be fair a little bit with Anthropic. You didn‚Äôt make a meaningful partnership and you haven‚Äôt found a way to get some of that compute.‚Äù On the hyperscaler comparison: ‚ÄúOf the three hyperscalers in the pre-AI world, Google was able to be relevant because they had their own model. Microsoft went and rented a model from OpenAI and now the contract‚Äôs nearly up and they did it to make a lot of capital gain but they didn‚Äôt actually in my view really develop something compelling that they own from it. And you did nothing‚Äîso you lose.‚Äù Lemkin added perspective: ‚ÄúOne thing we shouldn‚Äôt do here and you saw a lot of it with Google too is that you don‚Äôt want to overcompensate. There‚Äôs a bunch of bad news in one day and it is bad. But your position in retail is broadly good. You‚Äôre a little schlocking in terms of shopping experience but you have dominance because of your distribution and you‚Äôre doubling down on that. You‚Äôre reinvesting in robotics, you‚Äôre cutting costs. Amazon wins in their retail business because they can deliver shit faster than anyone else on the planet pretty much anywhere and you‚Äôre doubling down on that. So that‚Äôs like a win on the compute business on the AWS business. Your problem is you just‚Äîyou‚Äôre not relevant in the new world. So just knuckle down and figure that out.‚Äù iRobot (Roomba) had a $1.7 billion acquisition offer from Amazon blocked by the EU ‚Äúbecause of an incipient monopoly in the house vacuum cleaner marketplace,‚Äù as Benedict Evans sarcastically noted. The company raised $200 million in debt to bridge the deal. Now that debt is spent and they‚Äôre likely going bankrupt. O‚ÄôDriscoll was emphatic: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a horrible and unfair outcome for which the government and Lina Khan and the FTC is entirely responsible based on an outdated, stupid, and foolish belief about how things work beyond doubt.‚Äù The M&A Lesson: Lemkin explained the broader implication: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also a reminder that when you‚Äôre going to the M&A offer like Synthesia, sometimes you‚Äôll get the acquirer will pay a multiple that only sort of kind of makes sense‚Äîa revenue multiple that makes sense for them but you couldn‚Äôt get. And so when you get one of these deals, it‚Äôs tragic what happened to iRobot, but you got to take it.‚Äù Stebbings added the timeline problem: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a Synthesia, you‚Äôre looking at Dylan and Figma going, ‚ÄòGod, do I want to put myself in that potential 18-month waiting period?‚Äô This prolonged antitrust process really is kind of sand in the gears for a lot of these M&A decisions.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll provided the math: ‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòYeah, you got a 2.5x in 6 months.‚Äô No, you didn‚Äôt. You got a 2.5x in 2 years. And this prolongs‚Äîthis antitrust‚Äîthis prolonged antitrust process really is kind of sand in the gears for a lot of these M&A decisions and at the margin probably pushes people to either push on or in the case of the crazy deals when the acquirer only wants the people, then they do the Silicon Valley acqui-hire routine. But when you‚Äôre buying the vacuum cleaner company, you want the freaking vacuums.‚Äù The conversation turned to a technical but critical question: Should investors optimize for IRR or multiple? Stebbings made the case for duration: ‚ÄúThat duration period is also why I think it‚Äôs our responsibility as early-stage managers to be much more proactive in secondary markets because we get cash back way sooner. And the age-old thing of a 4x fund over 17 years is the same as a 2.5x fund over 10‚Äîand duration matters and time matters and IRR is king.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll provided the mathematical answer: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the only king because‚ÄîI mean back to Jason‚Äôs comment‚Äîlook, in this very show Jason was going, ‚ÄòOh, it‚Äôs only a 30% IRR Ramp from the 22 billion to 30 billion.‚Äô From an IRR perspective that looks amazing. So I don‚Äôt think IRR matters. I actually think the correct formulation of the optimization function is the maximization of multiple subject to a constraint on a minimum IRR.‚Äù He explained: ‚ÄúBasically you should know what your target IRR is‚Äîand let‚Äôs just say it‚Äôs 25%‚Äîyou want to maximize the multiple provided you don‚Äôt dip below 25%. That‚Äôs actually what you‚Äôre trying to do. So a 30% IRR in one year isn‚Äôt as good as a 25% IRR for four years. But if you hold on too long and that 25 starts dipping to 19, 18, 17, then you‚Äôve gone to a different place.‚Äù The reasoning: ‚ÄúIn the end you want the maximum amount of capital to invest and you get that because you are held accountable at the investor level at the IRR basis because at some point they‚Äôre looking at you, they‚Äôre looking at the public markets and they‚Äôre saying risk-adjusted I need my 20%. So it is the constraint because it‚Äôs what prevents money from coming down the spigot to you but you‚Äôre actually trying to maximize your multiple.‚Äù The mega-funds are real and here to stay. But as Lemkin pointed out, when you break down their individual fund sizes, ‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt think Sequoia having $200 million is that different than what Harry has‚Ä¶ So I just don‚Äôt think air cover is an excuse. You have to work twice as hard as they do.‚Äù O‚ÄôDriscoll agreed but added the caveat: ‚ÄúThe definition of a good strategy is if you have a strategy that doesn‚Äôt allow you to have to work that hard. And therefore by definition having 10 billion is a good strategy.‚Äù Revenue multiples are compressing for mature companies. As Lemkin noted, ‚ÄúGoing from $23 billion to $30 billion, I don‚Äôt even consider it an up round. It‚Äôs not enough‚Ä¶ You might go from 22 to 30 and have the same price per share.‚Äù Understanding your per-share price, not just company valuation, is critical. Stebbings emphasized: ‚ÄúYou have concentration of buyer unlike any other industry. Two buyers are 50% plus of every one of these labeling providers‚Äô revenue.‚Äù When a strategic acquirer offers a premium multiple, think hard about whether you‚Äôre really an IPO CEO. Lemkin‚Äôs advice: ‚ÄúAre you really an IPO guy? Can you really run a‚Äîdo you really want to run a public company for real? The weight of being a public company CEO‚Äîit‚Äôs so heavy today.‚Äù But understand the VC incentive misalignment: ‚ÄúFor the founder, let‚Äôs say owns 10%‚Äîwhat the hell‚Äôs the difference? There‚Äôs no difference. We‚Äôve had billionaires on our show. I don‚Äôt think Jeff Lawson would be living a better life with half the money or twice the money.‚Äù Factor in 18-24 months for regulatory review on any significant acquisition. O‚ÄôDriscoll: ‚ÄúYou think you‚Äôre getting this great multiple of‚Äîoh, they‚Äôre paying me 30 times revenue‚Äîbut the damn thing‚Äôs going to close in 18 months, by which time you might be down to 10 times, and it‚Äôs just not going to feel that much.‚Äù And as iRobot shows, Lemkin noted: ‚ÄúWhen you get one of these deals, it‚Äôs tragic what happened to iRobot, but you got to take it.‚Äù The Carter data confirms what great investors always knew: picking matters. O‚ÄôDriscoll: ‚ÄúTwo-thirds of all deals are less than a 2x which means they just don‚Äôt help. If you skew 75-80% in that less than 2x bucket, your math doesn‚Äôt work. And it‚Äôs not that hard to be that bad because on average it‚Äôs 66%. It requires a fair amount of discipline and picking to pull this off.‚Äù Companies like Mercor with massive customer concentration can grow incredibly fast, but as O‚ÄôDriscoll warned: ‚ÄúAt some point they‚Äôre going to say, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm giving you $200 million which means you‚Äôre making 30% on that‚Äî$60 million‚Äîhell maybe you do it for $40 million.‚Äô You prefer to be OpenAI and have 800 million customers than to be Mercor and have two.‚Äù OpenAI IPO Watch: O‚ÄôDriscoll: ‚ÄúEvery banker on the planet will be making decks as we speak calling on Mr. Altman and Mr. Taylor. They might pretty much do it for half nothing just to be on the biggest IPO of all times.‚Äù Mega-Funds Everywhere: The venture industry is bifurcating. O‚ÄôDriscoll: ‚ÄúThis is the dominant modality today. These are‚Äîthis is what top dog venture investing looks like. This kind of scale, this kind of dollars at work and there‚Äôs four or five other firms doing this.‚Äù AI Capex Super-Cycle: Everything from Mercor to OpenAI to AWS vs Azure is a bet on continued AI infrastructure spending. O‚ÄôDriscoll: ‚ÄúThis whole thing top to bottom is one big-ass bet on AI capex hyperrowth and as long as it keeps happening‚Ä¶ you got to stay on the floor and keep dancing.‚Äù As Chuck Prince famously said in 2007: ‚ÄúAs long as the music is playing, you got to get up and dance.‚Äù Private Staying Private: Companies like Stripe, Brex, and Ramp are staying private far longer than historical norms. O‚ÄôDriscoll explained why: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs really early and late-stage venture and then there‚Äôs venture for companies that already could comfortably be public and I think we need a different word for that‚Äîit‚Äôs not even late stage‚Äîit‚Äôs private as public.‚Äù The venture game is evolving faster than ever. The winners will be those who understand not just what‚Äôs changing, but why it‚Äôs changing‚Äîand what that means for where the puck is going, not where it‚Äôs been. Jason Lemkin on Sam Altman Having Zero Equity: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got Elon Musk arguing he deserves a trillion-dollar pay package‚Ä¶ and everyone was saying show Sam the money when he was fired as CEO over a very long weekend, right, the night of knives or whatever‚Ä¶ Fast forward to today, that same nonprofit is still in charge and he has no shares. We‚Äôve never seen someone own nothing, have we? Like this. Have we ever seen anybody own nothing? It‚Äôs crazy.‚Äù Rory O‚ÄôDriscoll on Microsoft‚Äôs Win: ‚ÄúMicrosoft corporate development and lawyers deserve a gold star from their shareholders in a way that frankly Microsoft R&D does not. And the proof of this is this morning Microsoft stock is up nicely. They‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòThank you for the hundred billion. We‚Äôre up.'‚Äù Harry Stebbings on LP Bundling: ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt often understand the stapling that is required to be in these funds, which is if you‚Äôre an LP and you want to be in the early stage fund, you will often very often with top tier brands have to put in two times that into another fund to get that $1 in the other. And you don‚Äôt get your pick of which fund. Very often you have to be across all of them.‚Äù Rory O‚ÄôDriscoll on The Spray and Pray Myth: ‚ÄúEveryone thinks they‚Äôre a great picker. Not everyone is a great picker. But the third sentence is you have to be a great picker to win. If you skew 75-80% in that less than 2x bucket, your math doesn‚Äôt work. And it‚Äôs not that hard to be that bad because on average it‚Äôs 66%.‚Äù Jason Lemkin on Public Company CEO Stress: ‚ÄúI was at this Dreamforce dinner. I saw maybe 10 public company B2B CEOs that we know‚Ä¶ and man, the stress on those guys‚Äîyou could just smell it out of the pores. The weight of being a public company CEO‚Äîit‚Äôs so heavy today. We could see it when we‚Äôd had Jeff Lawson on and Cliff didn‚Äôt have any of it at Canva‚Äîhe didn‚Äôt have any of the weight crushing.‚Äù Harry Stebbings on A16z‚Äôs Structural Advantages: ‚ÄúThat is a lot more money for management fees to pay great people. That is a lot more carry. That is a lot nicer offices which founders do get wowed by‚Äîlike it or not they get wowed by it. That is a lot more events to host where you can have serendipity. There are a lot more things I think that scale and AUM buys that do increase.‚Äù Founder SaaStr Email Address Company Job Title Email Address Get from $0 to $100 Million in ARRwith less stress and more success. Title: Dear Shopify Stock Fans, Mark Your Calendars for November 4
URL: https://www.barchart.com/story/news/35802899/dear-shopify-stock-fans-mark-your-calendars-for-november-4

Title: Casino Group: Third quarter 2025
URL: https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2025/10/30/3177792/0/en/Casino-Group-Third-quarter-2025.html
Time Published: 2025-10-30T17:30:00Z
Full Content:
October 30, 2025 13:30 ET | Source: Groupe Casino Groupe Casino THIRD-QUARTER 2025 Continuation of the first half-year's growth dynamic Growth in net sales: +0.5% LFL in Q3 and +0.6% over the first nine months The initial results of the ‚ÄúRenouveau‚Äù plan are confirmed, and the Group is again reporting like-for-like net sales growth this quarter. Increase in cumulative adjusted EBITDA1 at end-September: +13% Cost cutting and the bulk of the work already carried out on streamlining the store network enabled the Group to increase its adjusted EBITDA over the first nine months of the year: Compliance with the covenant and slight upturn in cash flow Improved free cash flow before financial expenses: -‚Ç¨39m at end-September 2025 (-‚Ç¨48m at end-June), underpinned by growth in adjusted EBITDA after lease payments. The Group reiterates that the basis of comparison was adversely affected by the payment in H1 2024 of ‚Ç¨153m in social security and tax liabilities placed under moratorium in 2023. After financial expenses, free cash flow amounted to -‚Ç¨198 million. The Group's liquidity1 stood at ‚Ç¨1.22bn at 30 September 2025. Covenant requirements were satisfied, with a ‚ÄúCovenant net debt/Covenant adjusted EBITDA‚Äù ratio of 7.68x at end-September 2025, below the threshold of 8.34x. The Group is maintaining its objective of returning to break-even free cash flow before financial expenses in 2026 and confirms the financial objectives set out in its ‚ÄúRenouveau 2028‚Äù strategic plan. SALES AND ADJUSTED EBITDA In Q3 2025, net sales amounted to ‚Ç¨2,002m, up +0.5% on a like-for-like basis, with convenience brands up +1.1% in Q3. After taking into account a -0.2-pt calendar effect and the roughly -3.5 pt effect of streamlining the convenience brand store network, Q3 sales were down -3.2%. Over the first nine months of 2025, consolidated net sales amounted to ‚Ç¨6,080m, up +0.6% like-for-like, with convenience brands up +1.1%. After considering a -0.6-pt calendar effect (leap year in 2024) and the roughly -2.9 pt effect of streamlining the convenience brand store network, total sales for the first nine months were down -2.9%. Group adjusted EBITDA stood at ‚Ç¨456m (+13%) over the first nine months of 2025, lifting the margin to 7.5% (+106 bps). Group adjusted EBITDA after lease payments amounted to ‚Ç¨112m (vs. ‚Ç¨59m over the first nine months of 2024). Monoprix Growth was driven by food sales (+0.9%), once again underpinned by a good performance in fresh products (+2.1%), particularly fruit and vegetables, which continued to benefit from marketing initiatives including the price repositioning initiated in H1 2025. Non-food sales were stable this quarter, as the Fashion & Home segment continued to outperform the market. Monoprix also continued to develop its "La Cantine" food concept, launched in April, with the roll-out of 3 additional stores in Paris and the Paris region, bringing the number of stores converted to the new concept by end-September to 6, with the aim of extending the concept to around 10 stores by the end of the year. Over the quarter, the streamlining of the store network resulted in the closure of 3 stores and the transfer of 3 owned stores to franchises at Monoprix (16 closures and 3 transfers since the beginning of the year). The brand also opened 8 new outlets during the quarter (19 since the beginning of the year). Franprix The positive impact of the "prix francs‚Äù (fair prices) campaign, with price cuts and price freezes on 50 private-label products, and the good performance of stores converted to the "Oxyg√®ne" concept, helped to support this trend over the quarter. The concept was extended to a further 25 stores over the quarter, bringing the total number of stores converted to the new concept to 75 at end-September, outperforming the rest of the store network (like-for-like sales growth of +2.3% over the quarter vs. -0.2% for the store network as a whole). Franprix continued to expand its quick meal solutions offer at end-September with the roll-out of two low-cost meal deals (breakfast and lunch).Changes within the Franprix network continued during the quarter with 24 store closures, 5 openings (64 closures, 22 openings and 6 transfers of owned stores to franchises or business leases since the beginning of the year). Casino/Spar/Vival This performance was underpinned by strong momentum in July (+3.6%) and September (+2.0%), ahead of a +0.3% improvement in August. Seasonal stores once again supported the trend this quarter, with a good summer season in the mountains for the Spar and Sherpa stores. Over the quarter, the Casino, Spar and Vival owned stores recorded a -1.2% decline in customer traffic (compared with a -0.2% decline in Q2 and a -2.9% decline in Q1).The roll-out of the "Coeur de Bl√©" quick meal solutions concept continued with 22 new dedicated outlets opened this quarter (36 at end-September) and 26 more planned by the end of the year. The new Spar "Origines" concept, which saw its first store opening in Luynes (Bouches-du-Rh√¥ne) this summer, confirmed the net sales growth prospects. The brand plans to open 4 more new stores by the end of the year, and to accelerate roll-out in 2026.The store network saw 98 stores leave the network in Q3 2025, 37 store openings and 19 transfers from owned stores to franchises (866 exits, 101 openings and 67 transfers to franchises since the beginning of the year). Naturalia This performance was boosted by a good momentum in the organic market, amplified by the effectiveness of in-store initiatives and the ongoing success of the "La Ferme" concept, rolled out in 3 additional stores this quarter (23 stores rolled out at end-September). The momentum of e-commerce sales continued, with +27% growth for the brand‚Äôs website, while Naturalia continues to expand its quick commerce business with the expansion of its Uber Eats partnership to 9 new stores over the quarter (47 stores at end-September). The quick meal solutions offer further expanded its roll-out: 3 new stores switched to the organic snacking concept this quarter, bringing the number of stores in the test phase to 9. Naturalia closed 1 store and opened 1 store in Q3 2025 (12 closures, 1 opening and 1 transfer from an owned store to a business lease since the beginning of the year). Cdiscount Driven by the marketing reinvestment plan, brand awareness rose significantly and new customer acquisition accelerated (+41% in Q3 2025 after +37% in H1). Cdiscount net sales fell by -2.9% on a like-for-like basis, reflecting the priority given to profitability through the momentum of the Marketplace and the moderate decline in direct sales. Cdiscount Advertising's momentum (revenues up +7.8%) continued with the launch of a new Retail Media product, ‚ÄúSponsored Brand Video‚Äù. Other and Quatrim OTHER FINANCIAL INDICATORS Free cash flow before financial expenses ‚Äì Continuing operations Over the first nine months of 2025, free cash flow before financial expenses stood at -‚Ç¨39m (-‚Ç¨48m at end-June), driven by growth in adjusted EBITDA after lease payments. It therefore improved by +‚Ç¨500m compared with the first nine months of 2024 (-‚Ç¨539m) and by +‚Ç¨347m excluding the repayment in H1 2024 of ‚Ç¨153m in social security and tax liabilities placed under moratorium in 2023. Liquidity7 at 30 September 2025 At 30 September 2025, the Group had liquidity reserves of ‚Ç¨1.22bn, including: These amounts are available immediately in full. Covenants Net leverage ratio7 The scope of the covenant test corresponds to the Group adjusted for Quatrim and, to a lesser extent, the subsidiaries Mayland in Poland and Wilkes in Brazil. The ‚ÄúCovenant net debt/Covenant adjusted EBITDA‚Äù ratio stood at 7.68x, below the ratio requirement of 8.34x. The Group states that the EBITDA forecasts for Q4 2025 should ensure compliance with the next test, which will take place on 31 December 2025. HIGHLIGHTS Real estate disposals Quatrim and its subsidiaries disposed of ‚Ç¨14m in real estate assets in Q3 2025. On 1 August, the Group repaid ‚Ç¨20m of the secured debt carried by Quatrim, enabling reduction of the nominal value of this debt to ‚Ç¨198m at 30 September 2025. Assa√≠ procedure Since the press release dated 26 September 2025 concerning the request for provisional measures submitted by Sendas Distribuidora S.A. (see press release), Casino Guichard Perrachon SA and Segisor (collectively "Casino") have had access to the file and Casino has presented its defence to the judge. The proceedings are in progress. Proceedings before the Paris Court Casino, Guichard-Perrachon was referred to the Paris Criminal Court following the preliminary investigation by the Financial Public Prosecutor (Parquet National Financier ‚Äì PNF) for alleged stock price manipulation and private corruption dating back to 2018 and 2019. The hearing before the Paris Criminal Court took place from 1 to 22 October 2025. The Financial Public Prosecutor requested (i) that Casino Guichard Perrachon be ordered to pay a fine of ‚Ç¨75m and (ii) that it be prohibited from making an offer to the public of securities and from having its securities admitted to trading on a regulated market for a period of three years, suspended in its entirety, and that it be subject to a compliance programme supervised by the French Anti-Corruption Agency (Agence Fran√ßaise Anticorruption ‚Äì AFA). These requisitions do not constitute a court decision and the Financial Public Prosecutor's requests are not binding on the Court. Casino Guichard Perrachon contests the fact that it can be personally accused of an offence and asserts that it did not, in any way, benefit from the alleged events mentioned in this dispute. The Group points out that no provision has been recorded in its financial statements in this respect. Judgement is expected to be handed down on 29 January 2026. Franchising of 27 Monop‚Äô stores The Group announces the franchising of 27 Monop‚Äô stores in Paris and the √éle-de-France region as part of the joint venture between Monoprix and the Zouari family (7 stores on 28 October, 11 on 29 October and 9 on 30 October). Refer to press release of 29 April 2025 APPENDICES ‚Äì STORE NETWORK Store network of continuing operations BL: business lease APPENDICES ‚Äì ACCOUNTING INFORMATION APPENDICES ‚Äì GLOSSARY Like-for-like (LFL) growthLike-for-like net sales include e-commerce sales and sales of merchandise excluding fuel from stores open for at least 12 months. The figure is calculated at constant exchange rates, excluding calendar effects and tax. Gross merchandise volume (GMV)For convenience brands, gross merchandise volume corresponds to the total value of goods sold by all the owned and franchised stores and the e-commerce sites, including VAT. For Cdiscount, gross merchandise volume corresponds to the total value of goods sold by the Cdiscount group‚Äôs websites and by independent Marketplace vendors. Adjusted EBITDAAdjusted EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation) is defined as trading profit plus recurring depreciation and amortisation expense included in trading profit. Adjusted EBITDA margin corresponds to adjusted EBITDA expressed as a percentage of net sales excluding taxes. Adjusted EBITDA after lease paymentsAdjusted EBITDA after lease payments is defined as trading profit plus recurring depreciation and amortisation presented in trading profit less repayments of lease liabilities and net interest paid on lease liabilities. DissynergiesDissynergies on operating costs correspond to the loss of economies of scale previously achieved through the hypermarket and supermarket activities and those of the former Latin American subsidiaries (Exito and GPA), up until their disposal in 2024. These costs, initially presented in the 'Other' segment, have been reallocated to the Group entities concerned as from 1 January 2025, in line with the implementation of shared support services. Free cash flow before/after financial expenses Free cash flow before financial expenses corresponds to cash flow from operating activities as presented in the consolidated statement of cash flows, less net capex, rental payments subject to restatement in accordance with IFRS 16 and adjusted for the effects related to the strategic disposal plan and the financial restructuring.Free cash flow after financial expenses is calculated by deducting net interest paid from free cash flow before financial expenses, excluding interest on leases restated in accordance with IFRS 16. Covenant ‚Äì Net leverage ratioThe covenant is defined as the ratio between "covenant net debt" and "covenant adjusted EBITDA". The scope of the covenant test corresponds to the Group adjusted for Quatrim and, to a lesser extent, the subsidiaries Mayland in Poland and Wilkes in Brazil. Covenant adjusted EBITDA‚ÄúCovenant adjusted EBITDA‚Äù or pro forma EBITDA (depending on the documentation) corresponds to adjusted EBITDA after lease payments relating to the covenant scope, excluding any impact of scope effects and pro forma restatements corresponding to future savings/synergies to be achieved within 18 months. LiquidityAccording to banking documentation, liquidity corresponds to consolidated cash and cash equivalents (less cash in transit and non-centralised cash), as well as undrawn and immediately available operating financing (excluding factoring, reverse factoring and similar programmes). Covenant net debt‚ÄúCovenant net debt‚Äù corresponds to gross debt relating to the covenant scope (including borrowings from other Group companies by covenant companies), (i) plus financial liabilities which are, in essence, debt, (ii) adjusted for the average drawdown on the Group‚Äôs revolving credit lines over the last 12 months (from the date of restructuring) and (iii) reduced by cash and cash equivalents of the entities in the covenant scope and by non-deconsolidating receivables relating to operating financing programmes reinstated as part of the restructuring. It differs from consolidated ‚Äúnet debt‚Äù, which corresponds to all gross borrowings and debt at the reporting date, including derivatives designated as fair value hedges (liabilities) and trade payables - structured programme, less (i) cash and cash equivalents, (ii) financial assets held for cash management purposes and as short-term investments, (iii) derivatives designated as fair value hedges (assets), and (iv) financial assets arising from a significant disposal of non-current assets. Analyst and investor contacts Press contacts Disclaimer This press release was prepared solely for information purposes, and should not be construed as a solicitation or an offer to buy or sell securities or related financial instruments. Likewise, it does not provide and should not be treated as providing investment advice. It has no connection with the specific investment objectives, financial situation or needs of any receiver. No representation or warranty, either express or implied, is provided in relation to the accuracy, completeness or reliability of the information contained herein. Recipients should not consider it as a substitute for the exercise of their own judgement. All the opinions expressed herein are subject to change without notice. 1 See definition in the appendices on page 92 Shrinkage corresponds to the difference between the recorded inventory and the actual physical inventory on hand in the store. It includes known shrinkage (broken items, items past their sell-by dates) and unknown shrinkage (theft)3 Including ExtenC sales (covering the Group's international activities)4 As a reminder, for the first nine months of 2024, the Group reported dissynergies on operating costs of ‚Ç¨37.5m in the "Other" segment. Since 1 January 2025, these dissynergies have been reallocated to Group entities following the introduction of shared services; they amounted to ‚Ç¨35m over the first nine months of 2025 5 GMV (gross merchandise volume): gross sales including tax; Product GMV: direct sales and Marketplace GMV (excluding B2C services, B2B and other revenues)6 Excluding restructuring and conciliation costs7 See definitions in the appendices on page 98 The financing documentation defines available cash as cash and cash equivalents excluding the float and cash not held in the cash pool; it corresponds to the cash held by Casino Finance, which operates the French operations‚Äô cash pool 9 As of the date of this press release, ‚Ç¨711m of the RCF debt had been drawn down10 No pro forma restatements have been taken into account11 International affiliate convenience stores include Leader Price franchises abroad. The last Leader Price franchise in France is presented within discontinued operations 12 International affiliate convenience stores include HM/SM affiliates abroad The SM stores in France are presented within discontinued operations13 The fall in the number of franchises/business leases in France is mainly due to the exit of master franchisee Puig&Fils 14 The fall in the number of franchises/business leases in France is mainly due to the exit of master franchisee Magne 15 Other businesses include 3C Cameroun Attachment Casino Group expands its Renouveau plan to 2030 and launches work to adapt its financial structure Operating and financial results in line with the targets of the Renouveau 2028 plan Following a... Casino Group Communication Paris, 29 October 2025 Further to the article published today by Olivier Dauvers entitled ‚ÄúCasino: Kretinsky r√©injecte de l‚Äôoxyg√®ne‚Äù (‚ÄúCasino: Kretinsky injects new...

Title: Fed Chair Not Worried About an AI Bubble. Here's Why It Differs From the '90s
URL: https://uk.pcmag.com/ai/161003/the-fed-chair-is-not-worried-about-an-ai-bubble-heres-why-it-differs-from-the-90s
Time Published: 2025-10-30T17:28:30Z
Full Content:
PCMag editors select and review products independently. If you buy through affiliate links, we may earn commissions, which help support our testing. Our team tests, rates, and reviews more than 1,500 products each year to help you make better buying decisions and get more from technology. Are we in an AI bubble? Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is not convinced. "This is different," Powell told reporters on Wednesday when asked about applying any lessons from the 1990s dot-com crash to today's AI boom. "If you go back to the '90s and the dot-com [era], these were ideas rather than companies," he added. "So, there's a clear bubble there. Whereas‚ÄîI won't go into particular [tech company] names‚Äîbut [today's top performers] actually have earnings, and it looks like they have business models and profits. So it's really a different thing." In other words, Powell believes businesses like Amazon, which reported $18 billion in profit last quarter, have ongoing revenue streams to keep the companies afloat, even if their AI ambitions don't pan out. An economic bubble is the "rapid escalation in asset prices, often due to speculative behavior, followed by a sharp contraction," according to Investopedia. They're hard to identify in real-time, but lead to "significant economic consequences" once they burst. The dot-com bubble of the late 1990s is one of the most notable examples, along with the Japanese economic contraction in the 1980s, and the Dutch "Tulip Mania" of the 1630s. Today, it's not speculative tulip investments that would bring down the economy, but data centers. The sums of money tech companies are pouring into them are astronomical, suggesting a high level of confidence that has sent stocks soaring. Nvidia just hit the $5 trillion valuation mark. Earlier this year, OpenAI, Oracle, and Softbank pledged to invest $500 billion in AI data centers over the next four years via their Stargate project. Yesterday, Amazon opened an $11 billion data center in Indiana, while Google, Microsoft, Meta, and others have similar plans. Data centers require a small number of employees, but building them generates temporary business for suppliers and construction companies. "The investment we're getting into equipment and all the things that go into creating data centers and feeding AI, it's clearly one of the big sources of growth in the economy," Powell said this week. He admitted he couldn't say if the data center investments "will work out," but does not think they will affect interest rates either way, which is his primary concern. (On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates by a quarter point.) Still, the AI hype is not translating into a hiring boom. Amazon just laid off 14,000 corporate employees, citing the need to move fast in AI (and pay for the GPUs needed to power it), which might climb to 30,000 in 2026. In June, Meta invested $14.3 billion in ScaleAI and poached its founder to lead AI at Meta, but recently laid off 600 employees as part of a team restructuring. When asked about whether AI is contributing to layoffs, Powell said it's too soon to tell, but it's an area the Federal Reserve is concerned about and watching closely. "You see a significant amount of companies announcing that they are not going to be doing much hiring or are actually doing layoffs, and much of the time they are talking about AI and what it can do," he said. "It could absolutely have implications for job creation. We don't see it in the initial [jobless] claims data yet, but it takes some time to get in there. We are watching that very carefully, but don't see it yet." The government shutdown is further hampering efforts to secure the federal employment data report for September. In its absence, Powell referenced "anecdotal data" from earnings reports, where companies are discussing a "bifurcated economy," meaning very different activity among high-income consumers who are still spending a lot, and lower-income consumers who are tightening their belts. "We think there's something there," Powell said. Other data points the Fed is using as a proxy for the official, federal report‚Äîsuch as unemployment insurance claims and job listings on Indeed‚Äîshow that the situation has been "stable" over the last few weeks, Powell said. Regarding tariffs, which have hit tech companies like Apple, Powell seemed cautiously optimistic. "Higher tariffs are pushing up prices in some categories of goods, resulting in higher overall inflation," he said. "A reasonable base case is that the effects on inflation will be relatively short-lived, a one-time shift in the price level. "But it is also possible that the inflationary effects could instead be more persistent," he cautioned. "And that is a risk to be assessed and managed. Our obligation is to ensure that a one-time increase in the price level does not become an ongoing inflation problem." My ExperienceAs a news and features writer at PCMag, I cover the biggest tech trends that shape the way we live and work. I specialize in on-the-ground reporting, uncovering stories from the people who are at the center of change‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs the CEO of a high-valued startup or an everyday person taking on Big Tech. I also cover daily tech news and breaking stories, contextualizing them so you get the full picture.I came to journalism from a previous career working in Big Tech on the West Coast. That experience gave me an up-close view of how software works and how business strategies shift over time. Now that I have my master's in journalism from Northwestern University, I couple my insider knowledge and reporting chops to help answer the big question: Where is this all going?My ExpertiseI'm the expert at PCMag for on-the-ground feature reporting and trending tech news, with a particular focus on electric vehicles and AI. I've published hundreds of articles and am also a podcast host, a bi-weekly tech correspondent for CBS News, a panel speaker and moderator, and a frequent contributor to a range of news and radio channels around the country.The Technology I UseAll the latest from Apple and Microsoft, but I'll never give up my wired headphones! I specialize in on-the-ground reporting, uncovering stories from the people who are at the center of change‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs the CEO of a high-valued startup or an everyday person taking on Big Tech. That experience gave me an up-close view of how software works and how business strategies shift over time. Title: As Amazon kills New World, League of Legends co-creator and Riot co-founder puts a call out for "star devs" from the MMO: "We‚Äôre always on the lookout for S-tier talent"
URL: https://www.gamesradar.com/games/mmo/as-amazon-kills-new-world-league-of-legends-co-creator-and-riot-co-founder-puts-a-call-out-for-star-devs-from-the-mmo-were-always-on-the-lookout-for-s-tier-talent/
Time Published: 2025-10-30T17:10:45Z
Full Content:
Former New World devs could find work at Riot Games When you purchase through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Here‚Äôs how it works. Fantasy MMO New World got the death knell from Amazon this week, as the company announced season 10 would round out updates to the game amid wider layoffs affecting some 14,000 jobs. Players and devs alike are commiserating, and now a co-founder of Riot Games has put out a call for the talent who are seeking their next gig. In the immediate wake of New World being sunsetted, someone tweeted at Marc Merrill, who co-created League of Legends and now serves as co-chair and CPO at Riot, stating that he needs to pick up some of the developers who've been set adrift. "Who are the star devs on the teams?" he says. "We're always on the lookout for S-tier talent who want to take on some of the hardest challenges and solve problems on behalf of the most dedicated players." The person who contacted Merrill states that a "Riot MMO" is a "massive need," likely referring to the online RPG the company announced in 2020. Where that project is remians up in the air, but the staff of New World probably wouldn‚Äôt be a bad fit for LoL, the still-upcoming Project F, and whatever else Riot is working on. They have experience handling a massive game through peaks and valleys, responding to the needs and wants of a global fanbase for four years. Who are the star devs on the teams? We‚Äôre always on the lookout for S-tier talent who want to take on some of the hardest challenges and solve problems on behalf of the most dedicated players. https://t.co/AeVrJ4UgjLOctober 28, 2025 Game-changing rollouts were part of their regular workload. In fact, the most recent expansion, Nighthaven, helped revive New World and put it on a more positive trajectory, making the recent turn of events even more heartbreaking, especially for players who‚Äôd stuck with Aeternum through thick and thin. In Merrill‚Äôs replies, Fabrice Condominas, an executive producer at Riot, sent the eyes emoji. With any luck, some of those now needing another opportunity can find one in the annals of Runeterra. Title: Update on Next Tomb Raider Game Is Surprising Amid Recent News
URL: http://comicbook.com/gaming/news/update-on-next-tomb-raider-game-is-surprising-amid-recent-news/
Time Published: 2025-10-30T17:04:00Z
Full Content:
By Jonathan H. Kantor A new Tomb Raider game that‚Äôs in development received a surprising update in October 2025. Since the first Tomb Raider game arrived on the Sega Saturn in 1996, the franchise has been one of the most enduring of the past few decades. There have been multiple titles, many of which have received widespread critical acclaim, and there‚Äôs also a feature film franchise and a forthcoming Amazon Prime series starring Sophie Turner. The last mainline Tomb Raider game was Square Enix Europe‚Äôs Shadow of the Tomb Raider in 2018. Since then, a mobile game, two remasters, and a collection have become available, but no new AAA titles have been released. The next game entered development in 2022, and it just received an interesting update. In late October 2025, Amazon announced a mass layoff of 14,000 employees, which had a significant impact on Amazon Game Studios. However, according to Variety, this didn‚Äôt derail the development of the next Tomb Raider title. The as-yet untitled game was first announced by Variety in 2022, and while it seemed the game would be on the chopping block, it appears it‚Äôs been spared. The same cannot be said of Amazon Games‚Äô previously forthcoming Lord of the Rings MMORPG, which was cancelled. Still, fans of Lara Croft and her adventure game series can breathe a sigh of relief, knowing development continues, though a release date remains elusive as of writing. The next game in the Tomb Raider franchise is being developed by Crystal Dynamics, with Amazon Games set to publish. The game will ultimately be released as a multi-platform title, although details of the story, gameplay, and other elements remain closely guarded secrets. It‚Äôs been in development for over three years, so hopefully, it‚Äôs nearing completion, but its release window is anyone‚Äôs guess. The game is said to continue Lara Croft‚Äôs story, set in an environment that rewards players for solving puzzles, creative pathfinding, and overcoming deadly enemies. Crystal Dynamics is developing the game using Unreal Engine 5. From perilous expeditions to adrenaline-filled Trials, Lara Croft is ready for every situation.The @tombraider Collection returns with two new looks: the Iconic Lara Outfit and the Shadow Runner Outfit. Now available (cont) https://t.co/wO5hNvRrr6 pic.twitter.com/wAHQugSlIQ Like other Tomb Raider games, fans can expect a strong, story-driven single-player narrative. Crystal Dynamics previously claimed its game would be transformative, and the developer is excited to team up with Amazon Studios. Following the announcement of mass layoffs at the publisher, which was launched in 2012, it seemed likely that every game currently in development would be terminated. While the layoffs did hit several titles, Tomb Raider and March of Giants, which recently completed its closed alpha, were spared. According to Bloomberg, Amazon Games is restructuring to support its cloud gaming service Luna with a focus on ‚Äúcasual and AI-focused games.‚Äù News of Tomb Raider‚Äôs survival brings hope to players who‚Äôve longed to return to the familiar and beloved IP since 2018‚Äôs Shadow of the Tomb Raider. That game was successful, and while Crystal Dynamics, then a subsidiary of Square Enix Europe, offered support, it wasn‚Äôt a primary developer. The game featured a continued story in Tomb Raider: The Legend of Lara Croft on Netflix. Now that the IP has returned to Crystal Dynamics (Now part of Sweden‚Äôs Embracer Group), there‚Äôs a lot of talent coming from a studio with a longstanding history with the franchise. Are you excited for the next Tomb Raider game? Leave a comment below and join the conversation now in the ComicBook Forum! Get access to exclusive stories on new releases, movies, shows, comics, anime, games and more!
